It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, often hairy foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone-rich soils, thriving in arid and semi-arid environments. Its leaves are narrowly lanceolate, with a silvery-blue underside, and it produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters. Due to its limited distribution and unique morphology, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
